You can set the guy as target, but you can't do it from the map or tracking station. If you can get close enough to see him in the distance (50km? maybe 25km) then you can doubleclick to set as target. I managed to rescue one person like this.

16 km isn't close enough to be able to switch to the kerbal, I think you need to be less than 3 km before you can take control of them.

To expand on this you need to be within 2.5km (I think it's 2.2km on approach) before you can switch.

The rescue missions are quite challenging without Tracking Station upgrades. It is possible to complete them, but the difficulty certainly is motivation to upgrade the Tracking Station. This is intended, so that upgrading the Tracking Station is not just to make it look better, but also to give it added functionality.

This is true and very important. If you've done these rescue missions before with patched conics and manouvre nodes you can do a decent job of it without them. If you can guess your way to being some 25-50km away, get out of map mode and double click the kerbal in the distance. From there it's just as difficult as it always is. When I accepted the mission without thinking too much about it I was also afraid that I wouldn't be able to complete it but it was surprisingly doable.

A few ideas for anyone trying to do a rescue without upgrades:

- Wait. Yup, wait. Put the rescue lander on the pad and wait until ImLost Kermin is directly overhead. The idea is you want to pull into an orbit a little lower than them right behind them.

- Before you launch, Mouse over their Apo and Perios and find out what height you need to aim for. When you get to 60-65k (best Isp), throttle back up and push your Apo to the Perio.

- Circularize as normal.

- If you haven't caught up to your target beforehand, try to line up your Per and Apo to their Per and Apo. You want to only be 1k off their orbit, slightly behind, slightly lower. Adjust this if you're way off.

- Eventually you'll get in range. Set target, rondevous as normal.

It takes more time but a lot less dV this way. At least for me.

An old trick for Kerbin rendezvous without maneuver nodes is this equation:

(Difference in orbit altitude / 5) x 12 = Distance from target at which to perform an Hohmann transfer burn

So if the stranded Kerbal is on a 100km circular orbit and I put my ship on a 75km circular orbit, I'll wait to be 60km behind it to raise my apoapsis.
